Problem:
Analyze a linear system modeled by \( Ax = b \) for a vector \( x \) and matrix \( A \), involving transformations by a function \( f(x) = Mx \) where \( M \) is a constant matrix. We assess causal impacts in the presence of this transformation.

If the transformation \( f(x) \) is applied to a vector \( x_0 \) solving \( Ax = b \), and then the system evolves naturally without further intervention, will the solution \( x(t) \) at \( t = T \) still satisfy \( Ax = b \) without alterations to \( A \) or \( b \)?
Explanation: Applying \( f(x) \) to \( x_0 \) modifies \( x_0 \) to \( Mx_0 \). Unless \( M \) is an identity or commutes in a specific way with \( A \), the product \( AMx_0 \) will not necessarily equal \( b \), changing the end condition of the equation.
